qas.question: What was the "escape" character originally intended for?

answers.text: to allow sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning

qas.question: What does modern ESC code do?

answers.text: most often used as an out-of-band character used to terminate an operation

qas.question: What does ESC generally mean for graphical user interfaces and windowing systems?

answers.text: an application to abort its current operation or to exit (terminate) altogether

plausible_answers.text: sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning

qas.question: What was the "escape" character meant to stop?

plausible_answers.text: an application to abort its current operation or to exit (terminate) altogether

qas.question: What does ESC generally mean for left-brackets?

plausible_answers.text: An ESC sent from the terminal

qas.question: What is most often used as a command sequence?

plausible_answers.text: In graphical user interface (GUI) and windowing systems

qas.question: Where does ESC generally cause an application to abort its given meanings?
What is an ESC sent to control characters usually in the form of?

context: Many more of the control codes have been given meanings quite different from their original ones. The "escape" character (ESC, code 27), for example, was intended originally <a0_0>to allow <b3_0>sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning<b3_0/><a0_0/>. This is the same meaning of "escape" encountered in URL encodings, C language strings, and other systems where certain characters have a reserved meaning. Over time this meaning has been co-opted and has eventually been changed. In modern use, an ESC sent to the terminal usually indicates the start of a command sequence, usually in the form of <b7_0>a so-called "ANSI escape code"<b7_0/> (or, more properly, a "Control Sequence Introducer") beginning with ESC followed by a "[" (left-bracket) character. <b5_0>An ESC sent from the terminal<b5_0/> is <a1_0>most often used as an out-of-band character used to terminate an operation<a1_0/>, as in the TECO and vi text editors. <b6_0>In graphical user interface (GUI) and windowing systems<b6_0/>, ESC generally causes <a2_0><b4_0>an application to abort its current operation or to exit (terminate) altogether<b4_0/><a2_0/>.
